Excuse me and this is being recorded at the end to HOUSECALL Braille and
talking book library in New York City and now Kara
why don't we start off can you tell me a little bit about how you feel.
Well and what got you interested in participating in this oral history

Hi I'm so happy to be here and talk about my
stuttering because no one ever talks about it. It seems to be the
silent issue. And. I thought
this would be an interesting topic and I when I heard about your
project I figured it would be something that would be of interest to
people in the future if not now. So I
decided to volunteer. So I started
to talk. When I was three which is a little bit
late. For.
Talking and. I always from that
time on had difficulty speaking. I had to start it.
One thing about stuttering that I've discovered is that
when that becomes an issue. As it did when I was. A
child because my parents were trying to do the very
best they could do set me to all kinds of speech therapists and
National Hospital for speech disorders and on and on and on a thousand
different places and the more. Of those
. People I talk to who are trying to help me
the worse my speech became. And I didn't realize that till I was
much older till I was in my forty's.
And so in school I had I had a hard I had a difficult
childhood because I became a severe stutter and
. I have to say today people don't use the terms
that are. Supposed to be people who stutter because we're not
supposed to be identified by the stutter I say who we
are.
I stayed around I don't care if someone missed out or it's fine with me.
So I still use the term but I guess you know for future use I wanted enough with that
that's not the Op Co want.
To turn to use so

lower middle class so we were on the poorer side but we do

And depending on the teacher I had and no

Get. Into the school
That decided if that was a good school year and so
. I had one school teacher I'm going to say her name because she was

teacher she didn't call attention to my studying she just treated me like anyone
else and I became somewhat more fluent in her class.
Then I had before my fourth grade teacher and I will not say her name because she knew
if she still lived although I don't think she is but I'm not taking any chances. I don't want to be
sued. She was the worst. She was actually a pro
if of. As you know ballet dancer
and only he was teaching so she could support herself and support her dancing
and I was a really good dancer and she wanted me
. To become a member of a Saturday

So she kept asking me. To join
my class but that was downtown Manhattan and I'm in the Bronx and

question. Who was the worst speaker in this class

It's too good of her to do that and did some damage.
Then in the sixth. Grade. I had
a friend of my wife of my third grade teacher they were pals

we all have to take this test. I didn't know was an I.Q. test but

Because I still started and not everyone. No starters and

And. We were in competition with each other was not a good

How come. You don't start it when you cheer.

you're just trying. To have an excuse for not. Walking. So
